name: Peking Duck
description: A famous dish from Beijing, known for its thin, crispy skin and tender meat. It is traditionally served with thin pancakes, scallions, and hoisin sauce.
ingredients: 1 bunch of scallions, cut into 3-inch lengths
instructions: Clean the duck and pat it dry. Using a sharp knife or skewer, prick the duck skin all over. Pour boiling water over the skin to tighten it, then pat it dry again.
Prepare the basting liquid by mixing honey, boiling water, soy sauce, and rice vinegar. Baste the duck all over with this mixture.
Hang the duck in a cool, dry, and well-ventilated place (like in front of a fan in the refrigerator) for 24-48 hours to dry the skin.
Preheat your oven to 375°F (190°C). Place the duck on a rack over a roasting pan with an inch of water in the bottom.
Roast for 1.5 hours, then flip the duck and roast for another 1-1.5 hours, or until the skin is a deep mahogany color and crispy.
Let the duck rest for 15 minutes before carving. Slice off the crispy skin first, followed by the meat. Serve hot with the pancakes, scallions, cucumber, and hoisin sauce.

name: Kung Pao Chicken
description: A spicy, stir-fried Chinese dish made with cubes of chicken, peanuts, vegetables, and chili peppers. It's a sweet, sour, and savory delight.
ingredients: 1 lb boneless, skinless chicken breast, cut into 1-inch cubes
For marinade: 1 tbsp soy sauce, 1 tbsp Shaoxing wine, 1 tsp cornstarch
For sauce: 2 tbsp soy sauce, 1 tbsp black vinegar, 1 tbsp sugar, 1 tsp cornstarch, 2 tbsp chicken broth
instructions: Marinate the chicken cubes with the marinade ingredients for at least 15 minutes.
In a small bowl, whisk together the sauce ingredients until smooth.
Heat a wok or large skillet over high heat with 1 tbsp of oil. Add the marinated chicken and stir-fry until cooked through. Remove the chicken from the wok.
Add another tablespoon of oil to the wok. Add the dried red chilies and stir-fry for 30 seconds. Add the diced bell pepper and scallions and stir-fry for 2 minutes.
Return the chicken to the wok. Pour the sauce over everything and stir quickly until the sauce thickens and coats the chicken and vegetables.
Stir in the peanuts just before serving. Serve immediately with steamed rice.

name: Vegetable Dumplings
description: Delicious, handmade dumplings filled with a savory mix of finely chopped vegetables. They can be pan-fried or steamed.
instructions: In a large bowl, mix all the filling ingredients together until well combined.
Place a dumpling wrapper in your hand. Place about 1 teaspoon of the filling in the center. Moisten the edge with water and fold it in half, creating pleats along one side to seal it.

To pan-fry: Heat a large non-stick skillet over medium-high heat with 1 tbsp of oil. Arrange the dumplings in a single layer and cook for 2-3 minutes until the bottoms are golden and crispy. Add about 1/4 cup of water, cover, and steam for 5-7 minutes until the water has evaporated.
Serve hot with a dipping sauce made from soy sauce, black vinegar, and chili oil.

name: Mapo Tofu
description: A popular and spicy Chinese dish from the Sichuan province. It consists of soft tofu set in a spicy sauce with fermented broad bean and chili paste, and a small amount of ground meat.
ingredients: 1 block silken or soft tofu, cut into 1-inch cubes
2 tbsp fermented broad bean and chili paste (doubanjiang)
1 tbsp fermented black beans (douchi), rinsed and minced
1 tbsp cornstarch mixed with 2 tbsp water
instructions: Gently blanch the tofu cubes in boiling water for 1-2 minutes. Carefully remove and set aside.
Heat a wok or skillet over medium-high heat. Add the ground meat and cook until it's browned.
Stir in the fermented broad bean paste, fermented black beans, garlic, and ginger. Cook until fragrant, about 1-2 minutes.
Pour in the broth and bring it to a simmer. Gently add the blanched tofu cubes. Pour in the cornstarch slurry and stir gently until the sauce thickens.
Turn off the heat. Drizzle with Sichuan peppercorn oil and garnish with chopped scallions. Serve immediately with steamed rice.

name: Hot Pot
description: A communal dining experience where a simmering pot of broth is placed at the center of the table. Diners cook various raw ingredients in the broth and then dip them in sauces.
ingredients: 4 cups chicken, beef, or vegetable broth
Slices of ginger, scallions, or dried chili peppers (to flavor the broth)
Vegetables (bok choy, napa cabbage, mushrooms, lotus root, corn)
Dipping sauces: sesame paste, soy sauce, sesame oil, minced garlic, scallions, chili oil
instructions: Prepare the broth: In a large pot or electric hot pot cooker, combine the broth with flavorings. Bring it to a steady simmer at the center of the dining table.
Arrange all the raw ingredients neatly on separate platters for guests.
Set up a sauce bar so guests can create their own dipping sauces.
Guests use chopsticks or a ladle to place their chosen raw ingredients into the simmering broth. Thinly sliced meat and vegetables will cook in seconds.
Once cooked, retrieve the ingredients from the broth and dip them in your prepared sauce before eating. At the end of the meal, the broth can be enjoyed as a soup.
